title: Is there a feature in Fontlab or a Python script that compares files and highlights the changed glyphs?
content:
Is there a feature in Fontlab or a Python script that compares files and highlights the changed glyphs?

 [‹ What are the worst typefaces of all time?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071202030832/http:/typophile.com/node/39210 "Go to previous forum topic") [Managing a LOT of fonts ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071202030832/http:/typophile.com/node/39575 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Eben Sorkin

comments.content:
Don’t know any such built-in feature. Writing a macro for that would be quite easy, however.

I can think of another, rather weird method: build an MM font with the old and the new one as masters. Those that are not compatible will not turn green so you have a first indication of modified glyphs. Then, generate an instance at an extreme extrapolation, say, 25000. Then you should be able to spot the changed glyphs – they will look strange and messy. I remember having done that once.

Tim,

an excellent solution — I never thought about this :)

A.
